p: There is much reason to be optimistic when looking at health prospects in SSA. To be sure, there are challenges but overall the burden of disease has decreased significantly. Norheim et al. note: “Except where HIV or war or other major political disturbances predominate, health and longevity are better now than they were 20, 40, or more years ago, and still improving …; a cost effective way to reduce premature death in many countries is to continue reducing child and maternal mortality, tuberculosis, HIV and malaria, partly because programs for these reductions that took years to establish are already in place and death rates are decreasing” (Norheim et al. 2015).
